item.title: It is time for the EU to address the origins of informal agreements in EU migration law when cooperating on migration with third countries.
item.description:
Dr CÃ©line Hocquet, Teaching Fellow, Birmingham Law School, University of Birmingham Photo credit: Issam Barhoumi, via Wikimedia Commons As the EU proposes yet another collaboration with a non-EU nation to manage migration beyond its borders, it’s crucial to critically examine the EU’s externalization policy and its use of informal cooperation. This analysis should consider the historical, legal, and political context of the EU’s external migration and asylum policy. From the EU-Turkey to the EU-Tunisia deal?..
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/it-is-time-for-the-eu-to-address-the-origins-of-informal-agreements-in-eu-migration-law-when-cooperating-on-migration-with-third-countries/
